ILL.name: Internet Leased Line
talk_track: Dedicated, SLA-backed internet access for critical locations such as HQ, data centres, and core branches.
Ideal where predictable bandwidth and low latency are more important than lowest cost.

BULK_FTTH.name: Bulk FTTH
talk_track: Cost-effective broadband for dense user locations such as campuses, RWAs, hostels and hotels.
Good fit where per-user ARPU is low but aggregate bandwidth demand is high.

SIP.name: SIP
talk_track: Modern, IP-based voice trunking that can replace legacy PRI lines.
Helps consolidate voice, scale channels flexibly and reduce call costs.

IOT.name: IoT Connectivity
talk_track: Secure connectivity for sensors, meters and field devices.
Enables real-time monitoring, tracking and automation across distributed assets.

MPLS.name: MPLS
talk_track: Private, secure WAN connectivity between branches, DCs and critical locations.
Best suited for regulated environments like BFSI, manufacturing and government.

CNPN_PRIVATE_5G.name: CNPN Private 5G
talk_track: Ultra-low-latency, high-reliability private 5G for mission-critical industrial automation.
Supports robotics, AGVs and dense IoT deployments in mines, ports and large campuses.

VSAT.name: VSAT
talk_track: Satellite-based connectivity for remote or low-coverage locations.
Ideal as primary or backup link where terrestrial options are limited.

SD_WAN.name: SD WAN
talk_track: Application-aware WAN overlay that can use internet, MPLS and 4G/5G links in parallel.
Improves cloud application performance while optimising overall WAN cost.

DATA_CENTRE_SERVICES.name: Data Centre Services
talk_track: Carrier-grade colocation and hosting with strong network integration.
Suitable for GCCs, IT/ITES and enterprises consolidating workloads into shared DCs.

WIFI.name: Wi-Fi
talk_track: Managed Wi-Fi for consistent, high-quality indoor coverage across large sites.
Ideal for hotels, campuses, RWAs and retail spaces with roaming users.

CCTV.name: CCTV
talk_track: End-to-end CCTV and surveillance connectivity for campuses, RWAs and public spaces.
Helps enhance security, compliance and incident investigation.

ISDN_PRI_SERVICES.name: ISDN PRI Services
talk_track: Reliable PRI lines for enterprises with existing PBX investments.
Good option where migration to full SIP is planned but not yet completed.

BULK_SMS_CPAAS.name: Bulk SMS (OTP/CPaaS)
talk_track: Enterprise-grade bulk SMS for OTP, alerts and campaign messages.
Critical for e-commerce and BFSI journeys where timely customer notification matters.
For low-budget educational institutions, the focus is on maximising coverage at minimal cost.
Bulk FTTH serves hostels and classrooms, with ILL and SIP added later as the campus matures.
Medium-budget institutions balance reliability and cost.
ILL secures core academic and admin traffic, with SIP enabling scalable voice and Bulk FTTH for student access.
High-budget universities push for fully digital campuses.
SIP and ILL together support unified communications, remote learning and always-on connectivity.
Entry-level coal operations start with basic IoT telemetry and secure backhaul.
IoT plus MPLS provides a secure foundation, with Private 5G as a future upgrade for automation.
Medium-budget mines look for more automation and centralised control.
MPLS secures traffic to control rooms while Private 5G pilots high-density sensors and robotics.
High-budget coal operations can justify a fully private 5G network.
Private 5G empowers autonomous vehicles, safety systems and real-time production visibility.
At low budgets, ports prioritise secure connectivity for core systems and remote jetties.
MPLS handles terminal operations while VSAT ensures backup in remote berths.
Medium budgets allow ports to expand automation and tracking.
VSAT plus Private 5G ensures robust coverage across yards and warehouses.
Smart ports use Private 5G for cranes, AGVs and IoT, with VSAT and MPLS as resilience layers.
This stack supports real-time operations, safety and optimisation.
Smaller banks and co-ops need reliable but cost-conscious connectivity.
ILL at key sites with SD WAN overlay gives them security and flexibility without full MPLS everywhere.
Mid-sized banks mix SD WAN and MPLS to support both core banking and cloud workloads.
SD WAN brings agility while MPLS backs critical regional hubs.
Large banks with high regulatory exposure favour MPLS for strong SLAs.
SIP and PRI complement this with robust, compliant voice infrastructure.
Global capability centres start with reliable internet and basic SD WAN overlay.
DC services can be phased in later as workloads consolidate.
Medium-budget GCCs focus on performance for global users.
SD WAN optimises cloud/SaaS traffic while DC services host critical workloads.
High-end GCCs run large shared platforms for multiple geographies.
DC services plus SD WAN create a resilient, high-performance core network.
Budget hotels prioritise guest Wi-Fi and basic voice.
Bulk FTTH keeps costs low; SIP can front-desk and back-office voice.
Mid-scale hotels want better SLAs and richer guest experience.
SIP plus ILL supports contact centre, booking engines and premium Wi-Fi.
Premium hotels require always-on connectivity for guests and operations.
ILL underpins everything; SIP and Bulk FTTH layer on top for voice and guest internet.
Entry-level hospitals prioritise voice and moderate internet.
SIP helps with appointment, helpdesk and ICU coordination while Bulk FTTH addresses basic data needs.
As digital health grows, hospitals need more stable connectivity.
Bulk FTTH plus ILL enables EMR, telemedicine and PACS access.
Tier-1 hospitals need mission-critical uptime for clinical and imaging systems.
ILL ensures low-latency access to applications; Bulk FTTH serves patient and attendant usage.
RWAs with limited budgets start with shared broadband for residents.
Bulk FTTH and basic Wi-Fi cover common areas; CCTV can be added as budgets grow.
Medium-budget societies want both connectivity and security.
Managed Wi-Fi ensures consistent experience; CCTV strengthens perimeter and common-area safety.
Premium RWAs position security as a differentiator.
CCTV takes priority with managed Wi-Fi and FTTH complementing the digital lifestyle experience.
Developers at low budget levels start with basic digital amenities.
Bulk FTTH and Wi-Fi provide value-add for residents; CCTV can be upsold as a phase-2 service.
Mid-segment projects differentiate with integrated Wi-Fi and security.
CCTV and Wi-Fi are positioned as part of the smart residential offering.
Premium real-estate projects push a full smart-community narrative.
High-priority CCTV and Wi-Fi combined with FTTH enable smart home and IoT use cases.
Smaller automotive units start with basic connectivity and pilot IoT.
Bulk FTTH and IoT SIMs help digitalise selected lines before a full WAN refresh.
At medium budgets, plants invest more heavily in IoT for production visibility.
MPLS then ties plants to central systems with predictable performance.
Large OEMs rely on MPLS for global supply-chain integration.
IoT and FTTH-based connectivity support smart factory and vendor collaboration.
Legacy-heavy FMCG organisations often start with PRI and basic MPLS sites.
SIP can be proposed as a future migration path to modern voice.
Medium budgets allow migration from PRI to SIP while retaining MPLS for key locations.
This balances transformation with risk management.
Large FMCG players run extensive distribution and sales networks.
MPLS is positioned as the core WAN with SIP and residual PRI supporting voice across regions.
Energy customers with constrained budgets keep a conservative tech stack.
PRI and MPLS serve key offices; VSAT is proposed for remote fields as they expand.
Medium budgets allow broader connectivity to remote assets.
MPLS plus VSAT ensures field operations stay connected even in remote geographies.
High-budget energy enterprises heavily depend on field uptime.
VSAT-backed connectivity sits alongside MPLS for resilient operations.
Smaller e-commerce firms start with communication-heavy use cases like OTP and notifications.
Bulk SMS/CPaaS and SIP give them reach while MPLS can be added for core sites later.
Growing players need reliable customer support and notification flows.
SIP supports support centres while CPaaS manages OTP and marketing journeys.
Large e-commerce platforms require secure backbone connectivity and omnichannel engagement.
MPLS interconnects DCs and warehouses, with SIP and CPaaS powering communications.
Entry-level manufacturing sites need stable connectivity for ERP and logistics.
ILL at plants with MPLS to HQ is a strong starting point.
Mid-sized manufacturers introduce SD WAN for better cloud and multi-plant routing.
MPLS remains the secure backbone for production-critical applications.
Advanced manufacturers run smart factories and multi-cloud workloads.
SD WAN orchestrates traffic across MPLS and internet, optimising cost and performance.
